main_text:
Classical Period
3. Classical Period

The first five hundred years of the common era also saw the redaction
of philosophical treatises in which proponents of diverse
philosophical and religious traditions put forth systematic versions
of their world views. These latter works bear witness, in a number of
different ways, to the intense interest in argumentation during this
period. Among the diverse forms of argument from this period, one
emerges as a canonical one. In this section, we first review the texts
relevant to the development of logic from the end this preclassical
period. We then turn our attention to surveying the emergence of a
canonical argument form. Finally, we conclude with a very brief
overview of the treatment of fallacies in arguments and of missteps in
debate.
hierarchy_title: Logic in Classical Indian Philosophy || Classical Period
